abstract: Study in journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences finds that corridors of land free from tsetse fly may have allowed cattle herders to reach southern Africa from Central Africa without being stopped by sleeping sickness that the fly spreads.
lead_paragraph: A recent study suggests that some people were able to use areas free of tsetse flies to travel south from East Africa more than 2,000 years ago.

headline.main: How Ancient Cattle Herders Avoided Sleeping Sickness
headline.print_headline: Ancient African Herders May Have Had Big Break

snippet: A recent study suggests that some people were able to use areas free of tsetse flies to travel south from East Africa more than 2,000 years ago.
